descriptionText
option.value:
Greatest Common Denuminator

The common algorithm to find GCD it is:
  • gcd(a, 0) = a
  • gcd(a, b) = gcd(b, a mod b)
More about this function on the Wikipedia.

option.name: text
option.value: fun gcd(a: Int, b: Int): Int = TODO()

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Fizz Buzz function

Implement fizzBuzz function that returns String that represents what should be said in the FizzBuzz game for each number between 1 and 100.

We list all this numbers in new lines, but we replace some of them with:

  • "Fizz" if number is divisible by 3
  • "Buzz" if number is divisible by 5
  • "FizzBuzz" if number is divisible both by 3 and 5 (by 15)

Print next numbers using print function

option.name: name
option.value: Fizz Buzz

option.name: text
text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Fibonacci numbers

In mathematics, the Fibonacci numbers, commonly denoted Fn form a sequence, called the Fibonacci sequence, such that each number is the sum of the two preceding ones, starting from 0 and 1. That is,

fib(0) = 0

fib(1) = 1

Then, every next number is calculated using:

fib(n) = fib(n - 1) + fib(n - 2)

Therefore:

fib(2) = 1

fib(3) = 2

fib(4) = 3

fib(5) = 5

fib(6) = 8

fib(7) = 13

fib(8) = 21

fib(9) = 34

fib(10) = 55

option.name: text
option.value: fun fib(n: Int): Int = TODO()

You already know how to make an entry point, but how does it translates to JVM bytecode? How is it possible that function without class is executed? Let's find out! (This exercise is for those present on the Kt. Academy workshop).

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Default

Default arguments are values used when we want to be able omit an argument 

fun cheer(
   how: String = "Hello, ",
   who: String = "World"
) {
   print("$how $who")
}

cheer() // Hello, World
cheer("Hi ") // Hi World
We use named arguments to set concrete one or to name an argument: 

cheer(who = "group") // Hello, group

option.name: possibleAnswer

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Factorial

Implement factorial function, that calculates product of all numbers from 1 to the argument, or 1 if 

factorial(1) = 5! = 1
factorial(2) = 5! = 2 * 1 = 2
factorial(3) = 5! = 3 * 2 * 1 = 6
factorial(4) = 5! = 4 * 3 * 2 * 1 = 24
factorial(5) = 5! = 5 * 4 * 3 * 2 * 1 = 120

option.name: text
option.value: fun factorial(n: Int): Long = TODO()

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Tree

Clean it up using what you've learned during the workshop.

Keep using StringBuilder.

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Nullability

Rewrite the following Java method in Kotlin in 3 lines: 

public static void sendMessageToClient(
    @Nullable Client client,
    @Nullable String message,
    @NotNull Mailer mailer
) {
    if (client == null || message == null) {
        return;
    }

    PersonalInfo personalInfo = client.getPersonalInfo();
    if (personalInfo == null) {
        return;
    }

    String email = personalInfo.getEmail();
    if (email == null) {
        return;
    }

    mailer.sendMessage(email, message);
}

Exercise originally published on the Kotlin Koans.

If you finish it and you still have some time, try different variants:
  • Without using Elvis operator at all
  • Without using if or when at all
  • Without using smart casting at all
  • Using only smart casting - without using equality sign at all
Compare them. Which one do you like the most?

option.name: text
text
name
option.value: Classes and objects

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Classes and interfaces

Implement class Businessman that implements Person Pass name and age as primary constructor arguments. Businessman is very polite he says hello by "Good morning" he cheers another person by "Hello, my name is {businessman name}, nice to see you {another person name}"

Implement class Student that implements Person Pass name and age as primary constructor arguments. Student is chilled out he says hello by "Hi" he cheers another person by "Hey {another person name}, I am {students name}"

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Factory Methods

Make a factory method that can be used this way:
val pizza = Pizza.hawaiian()

It should produce a pizza with 1 cheese, ham and pineapple same as this one:
Pizza(cheese = 1, pineapple = 1, ham = 1)

option.name: text
option.value:
data class Pizza( val cheese: Int = 0, val pineapple: Int = 0, val ham: Int = 0, val egg: Int = 0, val spinach: Int = 0 )
fun main() { val pizza = Pizza.hawaiian() assert(pizza == Pizza(cheese = 1, pineapple = 1, ham = 1)) }

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Update this product function to make it accept list as an extension receiver instead of as a standard argument.

You should allow this way the following use:
print(listOf(1,2,3).product())

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Tree operations

Implement the following extension functions:
  • Tree.plus(Tree): Tree - Returning a new tree by making a node pointing to the receiver on the left, and to the argument on the right.
  • Tree.count(): Int - Returning number of leafs in the tree.
  • Tree.height(): Int - Returning height of tree (longest size from root to a leaf including root).
  • Tree.contains(String): Boolean - Checking if any of the leafs in the tree contains an element equal (==) to the one from argument.

option.name: name
option.value: Tree Operations

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Tree Operations

Make + and * operators allowed for RationalNumber: 

r1 + r2
r1 * r2
To allow operator overloading, you need correct signature (name, arguments and return type) and operator modifier.
+ needs plus method with a single receiver and single argument.
* needs times method with a single receiver and single argument.

option.value: Higher-order functions

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Loop

Implement a loop function that repeats an operation infinitely. 

loop {
    // This should be repeated infinitely
}

option.name: possibleAnswer
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Flat Map

Analyze how onEach, map and filter are implemented.

Implement flatMap yourself.flatMap returns a single list of all elements yielded from results of transform function being invoked on each element of original array. Example: 

val l = listOf(listOf(1,2), listOf(3,4))
l.flatMap { it } == listOf(1,2,3,4)

(1..5).flatMap { listOf(it, it + 10, it + 100) } == listOf(1, 11, 101, 2, 12, 102, 3, 13, 103, 4, 14, 104, 5, 15, 105)

data class Worker(val name: String)
data class Department(val workers: List<Worker>)
val departments = listOf(
    Department(listOf(Worker("Jack Black"), Worker("James Roe"))),
    Department(listOf(Worker("Mick Kick"), Worker("Johns Rones")))
)

val allWorkers = departments.flatMap { it.workers }

Import aliases at the top are there to prevent you from using stdlib collection processing functions.

option.name: name
option.value: Flat Map

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Passing Students

Implement makeBestStudentsList method to display the best 10 students so they can get an internship. You should compare them by their result (higher is better). To get an internship, students need to have got at least 30 points in the semester and a result of at least 80. The best student gets \$5000, the next 3 get \$3000 and the next 6 get \$1000. Display students in alphabetical order (compare first surname then name) in the format {name} {surname}, \${internship size}

option.name: name
option.value: Best Students

text

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Generic functions

Make the following code compile by implementing a partitionTo function that splits a collection into two collections according to the predicate.

There is a partition() function in the standard library that always returns two newly created lists. You should write a function that splits the collection into two collections given as arguments. The signature of the toCollection() function from the standard library may help you.

option.name: name
option.value: Generic functions

option.name: text
placeholderText
option.value: fun partitionTo() = TODO()

option.name: possibleAnswer
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Response

Allow the following notation using variance modifiers: 

fun answer(resp: Response<Any, Throwable>) {}
val resp = Success("Hurra")
answer(resp)
val error = ErrorResponse(Error())
answer(error)

val rs1 = Success(1)
val re1 = ErrorResponse(Error())
val re2 = ErrorResponse("Error")

val rs1asNumber: Success<Number> = rs1
val rs1asAny: Success<Any> = rs1

val re1asThrowable: ErrorResponse<Throwable> = re1
val re1asAny: ErrorResponse<Any> = re1

val r1: Response<Int, Error> = rs1
val r2: Response<Int, Error> = re1

val r3: Response<Int, String> = rs1
val r4: Response<Int, String> = re2

val r5: Response<Any, Throwable> = rs1
val r6: Response<Any, Throwable> = re1

val s = Success(String())
val s1: Success<CharSequence> = s
val s2: Success<Any> = s

val e = ErrorResponse(Error())
val e1: ErrorResponse<Throwable> = e
val e2: ErrorResponse<Any> = e

option.name: text
option.value:
sealed class Response<R, E> class Success<R, E>(val value: R): Response<R, E>() class ErrorResponse<R, E>(val error: E): Response<R, E>()
fun main() { fun answer(resp: Response<Any, Throwable>) {} val resp = Success("Hurra") answer(resp) val error = ErrorResponse(Error()) answer(error)
val rs1 = Success(1) val re1 = ErrorResponse(Error()) val re2 = ErrorResponse("Error")
val rs1asNumber: Success<Number> = rs1 val rs1asAny: Success<Any> = rs1
val re1asThrowable: ErrorResponse<Throwable> = re1 val re1asAny: ErrorResponse<Any> = re1
val r1: Response<Int, Error> = rs1 val r2: Response<Int, Error> = re1
val r3: Response<Int, String> = rs1 val r4: Response<Int, String> = re2
val r5: Response<Any, Throwable> = rs1 val r6: Response<Any, Throwable> = re1
val s = Success(String()) val s1: Success<CharSequence> = s val s2: Success<Any> = s
val e = ErrorResponse(Error()) val e1: ErrorResponse<Throwable> = e val e2: ErrorResponse<Any> = e }

option.name: text
option.value:
import org.junit.Assert import org.junit.Test
class Test { @Test fun testSolution() { fun answer(resp: Response<Any, Throwable>) {} val resp = Success("Hurra") answer(resp) val error = ErrorResponse(Error()) answer(error)
val rs1 = Success(1) val re1 = ErrorResponse(Error()) val re2 = ErrorResponse("Error")
val rs1asNumber: Success<Number> = rs1 val rs1asAny: Success<Any> = rs1
val re1asThrowable: ErrorResponse<Throwable> = re1 val re1asAny: ErrorResponse<Any> = re1
val r1: Response<Int, Error> = rs1 val r2: Response<Int, Error> = re1
val r3: Response<Int, String> = rs1 val r4: Response<Int, String> = re2
val r5: Response<Any, Throwable> = rs1 val r6: Response<Any, Throwable> = re1
val s = Success(String()) val s1: Success<CharSequence> = s val s2: Success<Any> = s
val e = ErrorResponse(Error()) val e1: ErrorResponse<Throwable> = e val e2: ErrorResponse<Any> = e } }

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Consumer

Allow the following notation using variance modifiers: 

val c1: Consumer<Int> = Printer<Number>()
val c2: Consumer<Int> = Scanner<Number>()
val c3: Printer<Int> = Printer<Number>()
val c4: Scanner<Int> = Scanner<Number>()

name
option.value: Delegates & Builders

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Mutable Lazy

Implement mutableLazy delegate that works like a lazy, but value can be changed.

option.name: possibleAnswer
text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Last Run

You need a way to stop your loop. Add a method lastRun that can be used only inside loop. It should not start next run after this one. For instance: 

loop {
  if(it == 8L) lastRun()
  print(it)
}
Should print: 012345678

option.name: name
